questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger‚Äôs sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Measles

 

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads primarily through the air via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Its high transmissibility requires that patients be isolated in airborne infection isolation rooms to prevent the spread of the virus to others, particularly the unvaccinated or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, rabies does not require airborne isolation as it is not spread through the air.

 

Option C. Nipah: While Nipah virus can be transmitted from person to person, it is primarily spread through direct contact with infected bats, pigs, or other Nipah-infected individuals' body fluids. Airborne transmission is not the primary mode.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis: Generally caused by viral infections and not considered highly contagious through the air. Transmission is typically through direct contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibialis posterior

 

The tendon behind the medial malleolus that becomes prominent when the foot is inverted is the tibialis posterior tendon. This tendon plays a key role in foot inversion and is located just behind the medial malleolus, making it palpable during this maneuver. It functions to support the arch of the foot and assists in the inversion of the foot, which matches the scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: This tendon is located on the front of the ankle and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but is not located behind the medial malleolus. Hence, it is not the tendon being pointed at in this scenario.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: This tendon is responsible for extending the toes and dorsiflexing the foot. It is located on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent during inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon is involved in extending the big toe and dorsiflexing the foot. It is positioned on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent with foot inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibialis posterior tendon is located behind the medial malleolus and is most prominent when the foot is inverted. This anatomical detail is essential for identifying the tendon during a physical examination.

choices.text: Esophageal veins and left gastric veins
Left colic vein and middle colic veins

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic liver disease presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

 

In the given scenario of a patient with portal hypertension, anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.

 

In portal hypertension, increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in the dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

 

The patient's presentation of abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension suggests an obstruction of the portal venous system, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses. These are communications between the portal venous system and systemic venous system, which allow blood from the abdominal organs to bypass the liver and flow directly into the systemic circulation.

 

The lower esophageal veins, which drain into the systemic circulation via the azygos system, can anastomose with the left gastric veins (which are part of the portal system). In the context of portal hypertension, such as from cirrhosis, the blood flow through this anastomosis increases, leading to the formation of esophageal varices. These are dilated veins in the esophagus and are at risk of rupture, which can result in significant and potentially fatal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left colic vein and middle colic veins:  Both these veins are tributaries of the inferior mesenteric vein and subsequently drain into the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: These veins aren't directly associated with the complications of portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Superior rectal and phrenic veins:  The superior rectal veins are branches of the inferior mesenteric vein and drain into the portal system, while the phrenic veins are systemic veins. However, these two veins do not directly anastomose.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not play a significant role in the portosystemic shunting seen in portal hypertension.

 

Option D. Sigmoid and superior rectal veins: The sigmoid veins and superior rectal veins both drain into the inferior mesenteric vein, which is a part of the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not contribute significantly to the clinical features of portal hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of Porto-systemic anastomoses and their clinical presentations are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternothyroid

 

  • Sternothyroid and sternohyoid muscles attach to the thyroid cartilage and can help prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.
  • The apex of thyroid gland is directed laterally to the oblique line of thryroid catilage where it is limited above by the attachment of sternothyroid muscle.
  • The sternohyoid muscle, which arises from the posterior surface of the manubrium and the medial end of the clavicle, also inserts onto the thyroid cartilage and can help anchor the gland in place.
  • Together, the attachment of these muscles to the thyroid cartilage can help prevent the gland from pushing upward and causing compression of adjacent structures in the neck.

 

 

  • The thyroid gland is surrounded by the pretracheal fascia, which is connected to the larynx and enables the thyroid to move during swallowing.
  • The thyrohyoid membrane, a fibrous ligament, attaches to the top of the thyroid cartilage and the hyoid bone, facilitating the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.
  • The ligament of Berry, also known as the suspensory ligament, extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid gland, preventing it from descending into the mediastinum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland, trachea, and associated structures. It anchors the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring that the gland moves up and down with swallowing. However, it does not prevent the upward extension of a thyroid swelling specifically through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: It is a broad, fibrous sheet that connects the thyroid cartilage (of the larynx) to the hyoid bone. It contains the superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. While it's a strong structure, its primary role is not to prevent the upward extension of thyroid swellings.

 

Option D. Ligament of Berry: It is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the thyroid gland's posterior aspect to the cricoid cartilage and the first two tracheal rings. This ligament is a key anatomical structure that serves to limit the superior (upward) movement of the thyroid gland. When performing thyroid surgeries, the ligament of Berry is a crucial landmark as it is located near the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sternothyroid muscle originates from the posterior surface of the manubrium of the sternum and inserts into the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage. It functions to depress the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: A biostatistics professor is teaching a group of medical students about the fundamentals of statistics. She mentions a branch that is specifically concerned with summarizing and presenting data in a meaningful way. Which of the following branches is she most likely referring to? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Descriptive statistics

 

Descriptive Statistics:

 

  • Data is summarised through the given observations; summarisation is done from a sample of population using parameters such as the mean or standard deviation.
  • Descriptive statistics is a way to organise, represent and describe a collection of data using tables, graphs, and summary measures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theoretical statistics: Focuses on the underlying mathematical theory and development of statistical methods, not on data summarization and presentation.

 

Option C. Analytical statistics: This term is less commonly used and does not represent a standard branch of statistics like descriptive or inferential statistics.

 

Option D. Inferential Statistics: Involves using data from a sample to make predictions or inferences about a larger population, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

 

Additional Information

 

Applied Statistics:

 

  • Pure statistics focuses primarily on the numbers, maths, and problems themselves (theoretical)
  • Applied statistics on the other hand, can be thought of as ‚Äústatistics-in-action‚Äù or using statistics with an eye toward real-world problems and what their solutions might be.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics is dedicated to summarizing and presenting data in an easily understandable way, utilizing tables, graphs, and summary measures.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

 

  • The image shows a Vossius ring, which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity seen on the anterior surface of the lens.
  • It is caused by brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens and is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.
  • The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, producing an impression of the iris on the lens.
  • The ring usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil.
  • The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weiss ring: Is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

 

 

Option C. A Fleischer's ring: Is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

 

 

Option D. Kayser-Fleischer ring: Is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by which dermatome ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T10

 

The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

 

The T10 dermatome is significant because it corresponds to the umbilical region. Often, when clinicians check for sensation around the umbilicus, they are assessing the integrity of the T10 spinal nerve. This dermatome covers the region around the umbilicus, extending a bit below it.

 

Dermatomes are specific areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerves originating from a single spinal nerve root. Each segment of the spinal cord gives rise to a pair (left and right) of spinal nerves, and each of these spinal nerves carries sensory information from a distinct region of the body to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8: The T8 dermatome primarily covers the area just above the level of the umbilicus. If you were to draw a horizontal line around the trunk at the level of the umbilicus, this would approximate the center of the T8 dermatomal distribution.

 

Option B. T9: The T9 dermatome is situated just below the T8 level and above T10. It covers the region between the umbilicus and the midline of the abdomen, approximately at the level where the xiphoid process (the small cartilaginous extension at the lower end of the sternum) ends.

 

Option D. T11: The T11 dermatome covers an area of the anterior trunk below the T10 level but above the groin. It is positioned just before the first lumbar dermatome starts, and it sits above the inguinal ligament, which is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows:

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. –ú—É–æ—Ä—ñ–∞
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma ‚Äî exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth. (BNS 229)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (up to 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 7 years. (BNS 238)

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
‚úÖ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

üì∏ Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

üîç Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

üß† Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

choices.text: B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers

 

Explanation  

 

The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

 

 

Pressure on a nerve due to sleeping with arms under the head leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. B fibers, which are generally involved in autonomic functions, are not the primary concern in this scenario involving motor and sensory disturbances.

 

Option C. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. It's the opposite; A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers, making them more likely to be compromised under mechanical compression.

 

Option D. Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves: Incorrect. The loss of function is not due to sleep per se but due to mechanical pressure affecting nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situations where pressure is applied to nerves, such as sleeping with an arm in a compromising position, the larger, myelinated A fibers (including motor fibers) are more susceptible to disruption compared to the smaller, unmyelinated C fibers. This leads to a loss of motor function and normal touch sensation, while pain sensation remains relatively intact due to the resilience of C fibers to mechanical pressure.

 

Relative susceptibility of nerve fibres –

choices.text: Inferior vena cava
Right atrium
Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation

 

  • Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
  • Fetal heart pumps large quantity of blood into the placenta for exchange of substances.
  • From placenta, the umbilical veins collect the blood, which has more oxygen and nutrients.
  • Umbilical vein passes through liver, some amount of blood is supplied to liver from umbilical vein, large quantity of blood is diverted from umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava through ductus venosus.
  • Liver receives blood from portal vein also.
  • In liver, the oxygenated blood mixes slightly with deoxygenated blood and enters the right atrium via inferior vena cava.
  • From right atrium, major portion of blood is diverted into left atrium via foramen ovale. Foramen ovale is an opening in intra-atrial septum.
  • Blood from upper part of the body enters the right atrium through superior vena cava. From right atrium, blood enters right ventricle.
  • Then, blood is pumped into pulmonary artery. From pulmonary artery, blood enters the systemic aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Only a small quantity of blood is supplied to fetal lungs. Blood from left ventricle is pumped into aorta.
  • Fifty percent of blood from aorta reaches the placenta through umbilical arteries.

 

 

Mixing potentially occurs at 4 sites:

 

  1. Left umbilical vein (Oxygen saturation ~80%) – Portal vein (Much bypassed by ductus venosus to Inferior Vena cava)
  2. Left umbilical vein – Inferior vena cava – Portal vein (Oxygen saturation of IVC blood is ~65%)
  3. Superior vena cava – Right atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale)
  4. Pulmonary veins – Left atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Incorrect. While the right atrium receives blood from the inferior vena cava, it also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava, leading to a mixture that has a lower oxygen concentration than the incoming blood from the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava: Incorrect. The superior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood from the head and upper limbs of the fetus, thus having a lower oxygen concentration.

 

Option D. Ascending aorta: Incorrect. Although the ascending aorta in the fetus does carry oxygenated blood, the highest concentration of oxygen is found in the blood before it reaches the heart, specifically in the inferior vena cava due to the direct input from the umbilical vein through the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation is found in the inferior vena cava due to its receipt of oxygen-rich blood from the umbilical vein, which has directly exchanged gases in the placenta. This setup is crucial for delivering a sufficient oxygen supply to the developing fetus.

choices.text: Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids
Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray
Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT
Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma with breathlessness on examination is found to have systolic BP of 90 mmHg, SpO2 of 85%, GCS 8/15, absent breath sounds. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids

 

Following ATLS principles (A, B, C, D):

 

  • GCS 8/15 ("GCS below 8, intubate") indicates need for immediate airway protection
  • SpO2 85% with absent breath sounds suggests respiratory compromise needing ICD
  • BP 90 mmHg indicates a need for fluid resuscitation. This option follows the correct sequence of resuscitation:
    • Airway (A)
    • Breathing (B) - ICD placement
    • Circulation (C) - IV fluids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray:

 

  • Skips airway management in a patient with GCS 8/15
  • Atropine not indicated in this scenario
  • Imaging should not precede resuscitation

 

Option C. Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT:

 

  • Neglects immediate airway and breathing issues
  • CT scan inappropriate before stabilization
  • IV dextrose not indicated in acute trauma

 

Option D. Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery:

 

  • Ignores immediate airway and breathing concerns
  • Surgery evaluation premature before stabilization
  • Violates ATLS principles of prioritization

 

Educational Objective: 


In trauma, follow ABCDE sequence.

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is commonly used in neurosurgery and microsurgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nylon

 

Nylon is a non-absorbable suture material and is commonly used in neurosurgery, microsurgery, and ophthalmic surgery due to its low tissue reaction and high tensile strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyglactin: Polyglactin (Vicryl) is an absorbable braided suture material and is commonly used in general surgical practices for gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures, subcuticular wound closures, and ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option C. Polypropylene 1-0 & Option D. Polypropylene 2-0: Polypropylene is a non-absorbable suture material and is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair. Polypropylene 1-0 and 2-0 refer to the size or diameter of the suture, with 1-0 being larger than 2-0. These sutures are too thick to be used in microsurgery.

 

Therefore, options B, C, and D are incorrect as they do not match the given description.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What event takes place when the retina is exposed to light? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release

 

The retina responds to light by initiating a process called phototransduction, which converts light energy into an electrical signal. This process involves the activation of rods and cones, which are the photoreceptor cells in the retina.

 

In the dark, the cGMP gated channels in the photoreceptor cells are open, allowing a steady release of neurotransmitters such as glutamate. However, when light falls on the retina, a series of biochemical reactions occur, leading to the conversion of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal. This process activates transducin, which is a G protein-coupled receptor with phosphodiesterase activity, resulting in the breakdown of cGMP. As a result of the decrease in cGMP levels, sodium channels close, causing hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell.

 

The hyperpolarization leads to a decrease in glutamate release, which ultimately triggers the formation of an action potential. This process enables the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual images.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperpolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells leads to a decrease, not an increase, in neurotransmitter release.

 

Option C. Depolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because light exposure causes hyperpolarization, not depolarization, of photoreceptor cells.

 

Option D. Depolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is also incorrect as it suggests the opposite response of photoreceptors to light. Depolarization and increased neurotransmitter release occur in the absence of light (i.e., in the dark).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Light exposure results in the hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells in the retina, leading to a decrease in the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This process is crucial for converting light signals into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain to form visual images.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis‚Äîthe forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc
  • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brugia malayi and Option C. Brugia timori: Also cause lymphatic filariasis but have different morphological features in their microfilariae.

 

Option D. Mansonella perstans: Causes a different form of filariasis and has microfilariae that also have different characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are identified by their sheathed structure and the absence of nuclei at the tail end, crucial for the specific diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis caused by this parasite. This detail is significant for medical students and professionals working in endemic areas to recognize and diagnose the infection accurately.

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

 

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

 

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

 

The vagal trunks refer to the vagus nerves, specifically the right and left vagus nerves (cranial nerves X). These nerves are responsible for various functions in the body, including regulating heart rate, gastrointestinal activity, and respiratory functions. While the vagus nerves do extend into the thoracic cavity, they do not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Instead, they enter the abdomen separately.

 

 

 

The aortic opening of the diaphragm is an anatomical structure that allows certain structures to pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: It passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm as it descends from the thoracic cavity (descending aorta) into the abdominal cavity (abdominal aorta). This is a significant passage, as it allows the aorta to continue its course into the abdomen.

 

Option B. Azygous Vein: It drains blood from the posterior thoracic and abdominal walls. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the superior vena cava. This allows for the return of blood from the posterior part of the body to the superior vena cava and then into the right atrium of the heart.

 

Option C. Thoracic Duct: It is responsible for draining lymph from the lower half of the body and the left upper half of the body. It also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity and eventually drain into the venous circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Achalasia is a condition characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia), weight loss, and regurgitation. The typical radiological finding in achalasia is a smooth narrowing and gradual tapering at the lower esophagus, often described as a "bird's beak" appearance. The presence of dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis (bad breath) in a young patient, along with the image showing smooth narrowing, points strongly towards achalasia. The halitosis, though mentioned, is often not a significant feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca esophagus: This condition would typically present with progressive dysphagia rather than the intermittent dysphagia seen in achalasia. Halitosis is not commonly associated with esophageal cancer, and the radiological appearance would differ, showing irregular narrowing rather than the smooth tapering seen in achalasia.

 

Option C. Corrosive stricture: This would likely present with a history of corrosive ingestion and would show irregular, scarred, and narrowed areas of the esophagus, not the smooth tapering characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option D. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition can present with dysphagia and halitosis due to the trapping of food in the diverticulum, but the radiological appearance is quite distinct, typically showing a pouch at the pharyngoesophageal junction. The image provided does not suggest this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation in a young patient, along with imaging showing smooth narrowing and gradual tapering, is highly suggestive of achalasia.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl serine

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

 

Explanation

 

  • Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of dipalmitoyl-phosphatidyl-choline (DPPC) /dipalmitoyl lecithin. It is the major pulmonary surfactant (surfactant is a surface-active agent, secreted by type II alveolar epithelial cells) It is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions.
  • The most important components are the phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions.
  • The surfactant decreases the surface tension in the alveoli 2- to 10-fold, which normally plays a major role in preventing alveolar collapse.
  • However, in a number of conditions, such as in hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome), which often occurs in newborn premature babies, the quantity of surfactant secreted by the alveoli is so greatly depressed that the surface tension of the alveolar fluid becomes several times normal. This causes a serious tendency for the lungs of these babies to collapse or to become filled with fluid.
  • Clinical relevance - Test to assess fetal lung maturity is L/S ratio –lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. A ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidyl serine: Incorrect. While phosphatidyl serine is a component of cell membranes and plays roles in signaling, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not specifically linked to respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylethanolamine: Incorrect. Similar to phosphatidyl serine, phosphatidylethanolamine is a component of cell membranes and is involved in cellular processes but does not play a direct role in reducing alveolar surface tension or preventing respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylinositol: Incorrect. Phosphatidylinositol is involved in cellular signaling pathways and membrane structure but is not a significant component of pulmonary surfactant related to respiratory function or the pathology of respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and is the primary component deficient in respiratory distress syndrome, particularly in premature infants. This deficiency underscores the importance of surfactant therapy in the management of this condition.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2 concentration

 

Methods to confirm endotracheal intubation:

  • X-ray chest
  • Auscultation
  • End-tidal CO2 concentration
  • Chest rise

 

This is considered the best method to confirm ETT placement in real-time. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the exhaled breath. When the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea, it will produce a waveform with a consistent and relatively high end-tidal CO2 concentration. In contrast, if the ETT is in the esophagus or there is an airway obstruction, the end-tidal CO2 concentration will be lower or absent, providing immediate feedback to the anesthesiologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray chest: While a chest X-ray can confirm the placement of the ETT, it is not a practical or immediate method for confirming tube placement during intubation. X-rays are typically used for confirmation after intubation.

 

Option B. Auscultation: Auscultation involves listening to breath sounds over the chest and epigastrium to assess tube placement. While it can be a useful method, it may not always be reliable, especially in noisy clinical environments, and it may not detect esophageal intubation or partial airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Observing chest rise can be helpful, but it is not as reliable as capnography. In some cases, chest rise may be present even if the ETT is incorrectly placed in the esophagus, especially in cases of esophageal intubation with positive-pressure ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for confirming ETT placement is indeed the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.
  • It provides real-time feedback and is considered a more reliable method compared to other options, ensuring that the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea and the patient is being ventilated effectively.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by ‚Üí Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector ‚Üí Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis ‚Üí Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC ‚Üí Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY ‚Äì From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES ‚Äì Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS ‚Äì Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT ‚Äì Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-rebreathing mask

 

The oxygen delivery device shown in the image above is a non-rebreathing mask (NRBM).

 

Non-rebreathing mask (NRBM):

  • The non-rebreathing mask provides high concentrations of oxygen. It features a reservoir bag attached to it, which helps in providing a high flow of oxygen.
  • The mask has one-way valves that prevent exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring that only oxygen is inhaled.
  • The maximum FiO2 given by an NRBM is approximately 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: A Venturi mask is designed to deliver a precise oxygen concentration. It has interchangeable valves that regulate the amount of oxygen and ambient air mix, providing specific FiO2 levels. It is typically used when controlled oxygen therapy is required.

 

 

 

Option B. Hudson mask: The Hudson mask, also known as a simple face mask, delivers oxygen concentrations ranging from 40% to 60%. It does not have a reservoir bag and is less precise in delivering a specific oxygen concentration compared to the Venturi mask.

 

 

Option C. Nebulizer mask: A nebulizer mask is used to deliver aerosolized medications (such as bronchodilators) to patients. It is attached to a nebulizer machine, which converts liquid medication into a fine mist for inhalation. This mask is not primarily used for oxygen delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is an oxygen delivery device that provides high concentrations of oxygen, up to approximately 80%, and is characterized by a reservoir bag and one-way valves to ensure the inhalation of high-purity oxygen.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the hybrid muscle partially spared in a patient who presented with sciatica and tender hamstrings? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obturator nerve

 

The adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle in the medial compartment of the thigh, which is partially spared in cases of sciatica due to its dual nerve supply. The adductor magnus has two heads: the ischial head (hamstring part) and the pubic head (adductor part). The adductor part is supplied by the obturator nerve, while the hamstring part is supplied by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve. In patients with sciatica, the obturator nerve can still supply the adductor part of the adductor magnus, leading to partial sparing of muscle function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common peroneal nerve: This nerve supplies muscles in the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg and does not innervate the adductor magnus or any muscles in the medial thigh.

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: This nerve primarily supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh, including muscles like the quadriceps femoris, and does not innervate the adductor magnus.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: Although the tibial nerve supplies the hamstring part of the adductor magnus, it is affected in sciatica, leading to the involvement of muscles it innervates, unlike the obturator nerve which partially spares the muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quick revision of the hybrid muscles of the upper and lower limbs:

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JC Virus: Known for causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially in patients with severe immunodeficiency, but it is less common than CMV in affecting renal transplant patients in the early months post-transplant.

 

Option C. BK Virus: This virus can affect renal transplant recipients by causing BK virus-associated nephropathy, which can lead to graft dysfunction and loss. However, its peak incidence typically occurs slightly later than CMV.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): While EBV can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), it is not as commonly the predominant pathogen in the early post-transplant period compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and managing CMV infection in the early months following renal transplantation is crucial due to its potential to cause significant morbidity and impact on graft survival. Monitoring for CMV activity and initiating pre-emptive or therapeutic antiviral treatment as indicated is key to improving transplant outcomes.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contaminated

 

  • In surgical practice, wounds are categorized based on their potential contamination during the procedure, which plays a crucial role in determining the risk of infection and guiding the prophylactic antibiotic therapy. Here‚Äôs an explanation of each category in the context of an open cardiac massage:

 

This category includes open, fresh, accidental wounds and operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Contaminated wounds also include incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered. Open cardiac massage often involves emergency entry into the chest, which may not always comply with optimal sterile conditions, especially in traumatic or urgent contexts, thus falling into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clean: These are wounds where no inflammation is encountered, and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Clean wounds are primarily closed and do not involve placement of a drain. The risk of infection is typically the lowest in clean wounds.

 

Option C. Dirty: These wounds involve the presence of pus or perforated viscera. This kind of wound shows evidence of a bacterial infection or major contamination prior to surgery. Dirty wounds are at high risk of developing postoperative infections.

 

Option D. Clean Contaminated: These wounds involve operations on the alimentary, respiratory, genital, or urinary tracts under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Typically, these procedures involve some minor breaks in sterile technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

 

  • The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • The patient is also hemodynamically unstable, as indicated by the low blood pressure (70/40 mm Hg) and feeble pulse.
  • When a patient presents with SVT and hemodynamic instability, immediate rhythm conversion is essential.
  • The recommended treatment in such cases is direct current (DC) cardioversion.
  • This involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to restore a normal rhythm and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV adenosine: Adenosine temporarily slows or stops the heart's electrical activity and is often the first-line treatment for terminating stable, narrow complex supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). However, in hemodynamically unstable patients, its short-lived effects make it less suitable.

 

Option B. IV diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the rate in atrial fibrillation or flutter and certain types of SVT. In hemodynamically unstable patients, slowing the heart rate without converting the rhythm can be dangerous.

 

Option D. Ibutilide: Ibutilide is an antiarrhythmic drug used to treat certain types of atrial fibrillation or flutter. It's not the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable SVT and carries a risk of proarrhythmia, meaning it can sometimes cause new or worsening rhythm problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.

 

Ref: Miller‚Äôs Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1744

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that supplies the skin of the external ear, the area over the parotid gland, and the angle of the mandible. It is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically arising from the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the preauricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) traverses through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. Instead, it provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. Damage to the facial nerve may lead to facial paralysis or weakness, but it's not directly responsible for sensation or pain below the earlobe.

 

Option B. Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends into the face. It surrounds several structures, including the parotid gland. While the fascia itself isn't directly responsible for sensation, inflammation or infections that cause stretching of this fascia might contribute to discomfort.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal nerve: This is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin above the parotid gland, the external ear, and the external auditory canal. Though it provides sensation to the aforementioned areas, the region described in the scenario (below the earlobe) is not primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG2

 

IgG2 deficiency is the most likely culprit in cases where a child suffers from recurrent sinopulmonary infections specifically caused by encapsulated bacteria. IgG2 plays a critical role in the immune system's ability to fight off encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis. These organisms are particularly adept at evading non-specific immune responses due to their polysaccharide capsules, making specific antibody-mediated immunity crucial.

 

Transplacental Transport of IgG: IgG is unique among the immunoglobulins as it is transported from mother to fetus across the placenta, providing passive immunity to the newborn. IgG1 is transported most efficiently across the placenta, providing early defense against infection in neonates. IgG2, despite being critical for defense against encapsulated bacteria, has less transplacental movement, which can influence the susceptibility to infections in early infancy before the infant's own immune system fully matures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgG1: Predominantly responsible for protecting against bacterial infections, including pathogens like diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. IgG3: Often associated with a stronger response to viral infections.

 

Option D. IgG4: Less common and typically related to responses against parasitic infections, though IgG4-related disease can also manifest as fibroinflammatory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children presenting with recurrent infections caused by encapsulated bacteria, IgG2 deficiency should be considered as a possible underlying cause. Early identification and management of specific immunoglobulin deficiencies are crucial to prevent recurrent infections and their complications in young children.

questions.text: Identify the article in the constitution that is not related to pediatrics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 42

 

Article 42 says that the state shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief. It is not directly related to pediatrics but rather focuses on the welfare of workers and maternity benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Articles in constitution related to children:

 

Option A. Article 21 A: Right to free and compulsory elementary education in the 6 -14-year age group.

 

Option B. Article 24: Right to be protected from any hazardous employment till 14 years of age.

 

Option C. Article 39 E: Right to be protected from being abused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 42 is not related to pediatrics, as it focuses on working conditions and maternity relief, unlike Articles 21A, 24, and 39E, which are specifically aimed at the rights and protection of children.

questions.text:
A patient complains of persistent, dull, aching pain in both legs. He reports a history of extended periods of standing and mentions having visibly twisted veins in his legs. What tests would typically be conducted to assess saphenofemoral incompetence in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Brodie Trendelenburg Test
  2. Morrissey's test
  3. Fegan's test
  4. Modified Perthes test
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

The Brodie Trendelenburg and Morrissey's tests aim to assess the competency of the saphenofemoral valve, while the Fegan's method is utilized to identify perforator incompetence. Meanwhile, the Modified Perthe's test serves as a diagnostic measure for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

 

1. Brodie‚ÄìTrendelenburg Test:  The affected leg is raised so that the veins are emptied by gravity. Around the upper thigh region, a tourniquet is applied, sufficiently tightly to constrict the saphenous vein. The femoral vein blood flow isn‚Äôt obstructed. The patient is then asked to stand and the degree of filling of the saphenous vein is noted. On release of tourniquet, rapid filling of great saphenous vein is noted from above downwards in case of saphenofemoral junction incompetence.

 

2. Morrissey‚Äôs cough impulse test: Limb is elevated to empty the veins and then patient is asked to cough. An expansile impulse is felt on palpation at saphenofemoral junction.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Fegan's test: This is method is used to identify perforator incompetence. Site where perforators pierce deep fascia bulges on standing and depresses on lying supine, which can be felt as defects in deep fascia.

 

4. Modified Perthes test: This test is done to rule out Deep vein thrombosis. First veins are emptied and a tourniquet is placed around the thigh and then instructed to stand up. Then patient is asked to rapidly stand up and down on their toes and walk quickly for a few minutes. If filling of veins is observed, then this indicates Deep vein thrombosis. This is a painful test and is rarely used.

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image below. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dog ear correction
