The image demonstrates dog ear correction, a technique used to address redundant tissue that forms at the ends of a sutured wound. Dog ears occur when there are unequal wound edges or improper wound closure angles. The procedure involves excising the excess triangular skin fold at a 45-degree angle (as shown in panel 1), then removing the redundant tissue (panel 2), and finally achieving a flat, cosmetically acceptable closure (panel 3). The interrupted sutures shown are typical for this correction. This bunching of tissue resembles a dog's ear, hence the name. The technique ensures a smooth, flat scar without protruding tissue at the wound ends.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage of abscess: Incorrect. Incision and drainage involves making a linear or cruciate incision to evacuate pus from an abscess cavity. The image shows excision of redundant skin with primary closure, not drainage of any collection.

 

Option B. Skin grafting: Incorrect. Skin grafting involves harvesting skin from a donor site and transplanting it to cover a defect. The image shows direct excision and primary closure without any graft placement.

 

Option C. Keloid excision: Incorrect. Keloid excision involves removing hypertrophic scar tissue that extends beyond the original wound boundaries. The image shows correction of redundant normal skin at wound edges, not pathological scar tissue removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dog ear deformity is corrected by excising redundant tissue at 45-degree angles at the wound ends when unequal wound edges create tissue bunching during closure.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the eye: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Canal of Petit

 

Canal of Petit, aka Spatia Zonularis / Zonular spaces, is a cleft or sacculated canal surrounding the lens between the posterior of the zonule of Zinn fibers and aqueous humor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egger's Line: This is a reference line used in gonioscopy to denote the anterior limit of the trabecular meshwork, not directly related to the lens or zonular apparatus.

 

Option B. Lens Capsule: This is the clear, membrane-like structure surrounding the lens itself, not the space around it.

 

Option C. Canal of Hannover: This is another anatomical feature in the eye associated with the zonular fibers but refers to a different part of the zonular apparatus than the Canal of Petit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Canal of Petit is an essential structure in the anatomy of the eye, playing a critical role in the stability and function of the lens. Its correct identification and understanding are pivotal in eye health management and surgical procedures involving the lens and surrounding structures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock‚Äôs Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphuric acid: A concentrated inorganic acid that can cause severe corrosion and softening of the stomach wall, making gastric lavage dangerous due to the risk of perforation.

 

Option B. Strychnine: A convulsive poison that increases the risk of aspiration during seizures, making gastric lavage unsafe.

 

Option D. Kerosene oil: A volatile hydrocarbon that poses a significant risk of aspiration pneumonitis if gastric lavage is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

 

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock‚Äôs Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Pearl index

 

  • Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate.
  • It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharmacological index: This term is generally refers to the study and categorization of drugs based on their effects and properties.

 

Option C. Performance index: This may refer to various metrics used to evaluate the performance of processes or systems in different fields.

 

Option D. Efficacy index: While this might be used to measure the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin. By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity. P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs. Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism. Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include 
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium chloride: This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D. Triamterene: This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.
